node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

node.title: From 9/11 to covid-19: can New York recover?

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text: The number of working-age people in China is shrinking. Could this threaten the country’s rise as an economic superpower? Credit: Eyevine

node.title: China’s economy: what’s its weak spot?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 16, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'News SpaceX sends the first-ever civilian crew into Earth orbit'.

node.text:
If you know where to look, the progress of SpaceX’s #Inspiration4 mission will be visible in clear night skies around the world.⁠
⁠
Unlike the trips of Richard Branson and Jeff Bezos, the rocket has gone all the way to orbit. ⁠
⁠
And on Sunday, after more than 40 orbits, the crew of four civilian astronauts will re-enter the atmosphere.. ⁠
⁠
This latest billionaire space mission is the most ambitious yet—and is being chronicled in a Netflix documentary series. ⁠
⁠
Would you like to take a trip into orbit? To learn what the flight means for the future of space travel, tap on the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Florida Today via AP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
Versions of layered, nutty pastries may have been made as early as the eighth century BC by the Assyrians, but it was the Ottomans who perfected the sticky glory of baklava.⁠
⁠
Even without the sultans and their acolytes, baklava still evokes a sense of ceremony. Feast days, religious or otherwise, to celebrate both the living and the dead, are occasions for the sweet.⁠
⁠
So, too, are visits by friends. The food writer Claudia Roden, from an Egyptian-Jewish family, said that baklava brings “feelings of well-being, warmth and welcome, of giving and receiving, of crowds of people smiling, kissing, hugging and showering hospitality”.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read about baklava's multilayered history.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Albane Simon

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New Delhi. May be a cartoon of text that says 'Asia The dark side of India's ingrained caste system A'.

node.text:
India’s caste system remains entrenched, 75 years after independence. ⁠
⁠
The evil of India’s caste practice is almost as old as the gods, and is the most noxious and evolved example today of how humans attempt to impose superiority and suffering on others by virtue of their birth.⁠
⁠
On top are the Brahmins or priestly caste and at the bottom are the Shudras or labouring castes. The rest do not even count: outcastes.⁠
⁠
In the 1980s  a commission of inquiry deemed 52% of Indians to be members of a new category, “other backward classes”, eligible for reserved public jobs.⁠
⁠
Despite the Supreme Court ruling of no more than 50% of public jobs can be reserved, states regularly breach the limit. Click the link in our bio to read the consequences of affirmative action for the majority.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @elenaxausa

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Asia The arms race on the Korean peninsula is intensifying 北,탄도미사일2발발사 연합뉴스TV 14:30 홍산31 ២量673% 지성림기자 국방부 료화면 항미사일 시험발사 공개 이틀 정부 접종자 인센티브 확대'.

node.text:
Observers of military developments on the Korean peninsula might have got whiplash on September 15th. First, news broke that North Korea had fired two ballistic missiles off its east coast. Shortly afterwards the South Korean government announced that Moon Jae-in, the president, had observed the successful test of a submarine-launched ballistic missile.⁠
⁠
The parallel tests highlight an accelerating arms race on the peninsula.⁠
⁠
North Korea has continued to expand both its nuclear and its conventional arsenal, in the face of UN sanctions that ban it from developing nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles. Meanwhile South Korea has been ramping up defence spending and expanding its own arsenal. ⁠
⁠
The restoration of a communications link between the two Koreas in June (following the demolition of a joint liaison office by the North a year earlier) did not lead to a wider detente. Then the North stopped returning the South’s calls ahead of joint military exercises between the South and America in mid-August.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read why diplomatic efforts to defuse tensions on the peninsula have been deadlocked since a brief thaw in 2018 and 2019.⁠
⁠
Credit: Chung Sung-Jun/Getty Images

node.text:
Are booster vaccines for covid-19 necessary? On our “Babbage” podcast, we explore the science and ethics behind recent moves in some countries to roll out third doses of vaccines.⁠
⁠
Soumya Swaminathan of the World Health Organisation, and Natasha Loder, The Economist’s health-policy editor, join the podcast. Also in this episode, a study in Bangladesh finds simple ways to encourage mask use, and we reveal our book competition winner.⁠
⁠
To understand more about new perspectives in vaccine rollouts, click the link in our bio to listen to “Babbage”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Today Zionism—the Christian Catholic Apostolic Church in Zion—is the largest religious movement in southern Africa, with 15m followers.⁠
⁠
John Alexander Dowie’s church, known as the Christian Catholic Apostolic Church in Zion, originated in Chicago in 1892 and from there, missionaries tried to spread its teachings.⁠
⁠
Zionism took off in another newly seething metropolis: Johannesburg. The religion blends Christian teachings with African traditions like ancestor worship, although some American evangelicals are unhappy about this.⁠
⁠
But the biggest challenge to Zionism is from Pentecostalism, perhaps the fastest-growing religion in southern Africa.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read how Zionism is evolving. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Brooks Kraft LLC/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 15, 2021. May be an illustration of 2 people.

node.text:
The weight of society’s expectations is hardly a new phenomenon but it has become particularly draining over recent decades. ⁠
⁠
Perfectionism is slippery. Clinically it is reflected in a dizzying range of symptoms: depression and anxiety, obsessional disorders, psychosomatic illness, suicidal thoughts, body dysmorphia and eating disorders.⁠
⁠
This also means that perfectionism can grow from the soil of very different childhood experiences, as psychoanalyst Josh Cohen explains. ⁠
⁠
Whichever way you approach parenting, you may end up stoking your children’s desperate need to please and create a lifelong difficulty in distinguishing their own desires from your aspirations for them.⁠
⁠
The sweet spot between over-involvement and under-involvement in our children’s lives is maddeningly elusive.⁠
⁠
Click the link in bio to read more on why it's so hard to get parenting right.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Adam Simpson

node.text:
When Delta arrived in Vietnam, the highly contagious variant moved too quickly for the authorities to contain it.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In 2020, Vietnam recorded mostly single-digit numbers of covid-19 until April, before a surge that saw daily cases rise to over 13,000 by early September.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Likewise in Cambodia, where an outbreak of the virus—was virtually unknown until April 2020—was set off by just two people.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
South-East Asia has seen an enormous rise in infections and deaths from covid-19 over the past few months, as the Delta variant hit the region hard. Swipe to the second chart.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how many countries there have now abandoned their early-pandemic policies and are instead focusing on vaccination efforts.

Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of text that says '"It " It seems as if the surest way to curse one's nation is to subordinate its women Authors of a study that ranks 176 countries for misogyny'.

node.text:
Researchers have found patriarchy to be a better predictor of violent instability than income, urbanisation or bad governance.⁠
⁠
The study, by Valerie Hudson, Donna Lee Bowen and Perpetua Lynne Nielsen of Texas A&M and Brigham Young universities, estimates that 120 countries are still to some degree swayed by pre-modern attitudes to women that endanger political stability.⁠
⁠
If women are subject to autocracy and terror in their homes, society is also more vulnerable to these ills. ⁠
⁠
A composite measure of archaic attitudes to women explained three-quarters of the variation in a country’s score on the Fragile States index compiled by the Fund for Peace. ⁠
⁠
The researchers also found evidence that patriarchy and poverty go hand in hand.⁠
⁠
To read how the most sexist societies work, and why oppressing women comes at a great cost, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Asia A journey from Kabul to Kandahar, a month after the Taliban took power'.

node.text:
This is part of the nearly 500km section of Highway 1 that links Afghanistan’s capital, Kabul, to its second city, Kandahar. Just weeks ago, this was a perilous route.⁠
⁠
Taliban fighters held up traffic, ambushed convoys and killed government workers.⁠
⁠
Now the very fighters who once attacked the road are standing guard along it. ⁠
⁠
There are deep ruts in the decaying asphalt. The traffic passes the ghosts of American posts as it slaloms around craters left by roadside bombs. ⁠
⁠
A month after the Islamists took power, the journey from Kabul to Kandahar gives an illustration both of how the country changed overnight and of the failures that helped bring about the change.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read our correspondent’s account, and what it says about Afghanistan’s old problems and new challenges.⁠
⁠
Credit: Marcus Yam, Los Angeles Times

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 14, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text.

node.text:
It seemed like a blustery overpromise when President Joe Biden pledged in July to oversee “the largest ever one-year decrease in child poverty in the history of the United States”. By the end of the year, however, he will probably turn out to have been correct.⁠
⁠
Recent modelling by scholars at Columbia University estimates that in July child poverty was 41% lower than normal.⁠
⁠
The number of households with children that reported not having enough food in the past week dropped substantially after the first child-tax-credit payment began—going from 13.7% to 9.5%. At full coverage, poverty for black children would drop from its present estimate of 18.4% to 13.6%; for Hispanic children from 16.8% to 14.1%.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read why the Biden administration’s biggest success has not received enough attention.⁠
⁠
Credit: Eyevine

node.text:
“Hybrid” reefs have been around for a while, but now they are being deployed in surprising ways.⁠
⁠
Artificial coral reefs co-opt the local ecology to help out. Fully grown, they are a defence against erosion and wave damage—and a tourist attraction for divers.⁠
⁠
In a warming world with rising sea levels, coral reef defence is likely to have widespread appeal. However, even artificial reefs are not immune to climate change. ⁠
⁠
Perhaps the biggest challenge is to ensure that hybrid reefs survive altered environmental conditions, including seawater that is getting warmer and more acidic. ⁠
⁠
To read why hybrid reefs are gaining the attention of commercial developers, and even the military, tap the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
